data.title: Must-Read Books About Modern Cinema, Movies and the People Who Make Them
data.meta_description: New additions look at the life of Arnold Schwarzenegger, the work of Ruth E. Carter and more.
data.text:
When it comes to literary recommendations for aspiring filmmakers and lovers of movies in general, there are certain titles that have stood the test of time: Akira Kurosawa's Something Like an Autobiography, and Sidney Lumet's Making Movies, and Robert Rodriguez's Rebel Without a Crew — to say nothing of Save the Cat! by Blake Snyder.

But as each year brings new movies to theaters, it also brings new books to our shelves. Below, A.frame has compiled a list of recently-published volumes those would-be directors and cinephiles need to add to their reading lists, including books that frame (or reframe) the byzantine history of Hollywood, and works looking at specific movies, filmmakers, genres and more. The latest additions to the list include insights into the making of Star Wars and a deep dive into the life and legacy of Arnold Schwarzenegger.

'ARNOLD' by Dian Hanson

Arnold Schwarzenegger has lived many lives: He's been a four-time Mr. Universe-winning bodybuilder, one of history's most-recognized movie stars, and the Governor of California. This two-volume tome by TASCHEN looks back on his many varied accomplishments, tracking Schwarzenegger's journey from his childhood in Austria to his rise in Hollywood and beyond via portraits by the likes of Annie Leibovitz, Robert Mapplethorpe, and Andy Warhol, as well as unseen photos from Arnie's personal archives.

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'Age of Cage: Four Decades of Hollywood Through One Singular Career' by Keith Phipps

Something of a companion piece to the delightfully meta The Unbearable Weight of Massive Talent, journalist and critic Keith Phipps' Age of Cage attempts to understand the man behind the mythos by studying Nicolas Cage's filmography, juxtaposed with the ever-changing landscape of Hollywood. (Maybe it's worth mentioning, due to its subsequent placement on this list, that Cage does not consider himself a Method actor, but subscribes to a style he calls "nouveau shamanism.")

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'A Long Time Ago in a Cutting Room Far, Far Away' by Paul Hirsch

The subtitle of Paul Hirsch's memoir is "My Fifty Years Editing Hollywood Hits — Star Wars, Carrie, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, Mission: Impossible, and More," which is exactly what this book is: A movie-by-movie breakdown of the Oscar-winning editor's career (he won Best Film Editing for the 1977 space opera that provides the book its title), providing behind-the-scenes stories of working on films by George Lucas, Brian De Palma, Herbert Ross and John Hughes, among others.

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'The Art of Ruth E. Carter' by Ruth E. Carter

Ruth E. Carter is a living legend, having made history as the first Black woman ever to win two Oscars. (Carter won Best Costume Design for both Black Panther and its sequel, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever). This book, subtitled "Costuming Black History and the Afrofuture, from Do the Right Thing to Black Panther," offers a closer look at her work, full of exclusive photos and costume sketches of the costumes for Amistad, Malcolm X, Coming 2 America and many, many more.

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'Audience-ology: How Moviegoers Shape the Films We Love' by Kevin Goetz

There are numerous books about what goes into making a movie — about directing and writing and cinematography and editing — but rare is the book about how to make a movie that audiences will love. Kevin Goetz, known as "the doctor of audience-ology," pulls back the curtain on test screenings through his own work on movies over the years, as well as interviews with the likes of Ron Howard, Jason Blum and more.

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'The Big Goodbye: Chinatown and the Last Years of Hollywood' by Sam Wasson

Chinatown won the Oscar for Best Original Screenplay — awarded to Robert Towne for what is widely considered one of the greatest screenplays ever written — but it turns out the behind-the-scenes story of how this neo-noir classic was made is as enthralling as what was captured on-screen, as unveiled in Sam Wasson's The Big Goodbye.

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'Byways' by Roger Deakins

This monograph by legendary two-time Oscar-winning cinematographer Sir Roger Deakins (Blade Runner 2049 and 1917) compiles more than 50 years' worth of his black-and-white photography, spanning from his youth in seaside England in the 1960s to recent shots taken between his time on various movie sets. "It was very much a sort of personal project," Deakins tells A.frame. "I just thought it would just be nice to put them together. And I don't really like the internet so much — I like having something hard copy — so that's where it came from."

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'Camera Man: Buster Keaton, the Dawn of Cinema, and the Invention of the Twentieth Century' by Dana Stevens

Buster Keaton was born in 1895, the same year that the Lumiére Brothers invented the Cinématographe, the revolutionary three-in-one device that could record, develop, and project motion pictures. Camera Man is less-so another biography of Buster Keaton, but instead a study of how the comedian and the film industry came of age at the same time. Critic Dana Stevens deftly examines how Keaton was a reflection of the world around him and crafts a complex portrait of both the star and the early days of cinema.

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial: The Ultimate Visual History' by Caseen Gaines

Documenting the complete history of E.T., the book explores Steven Spielberg's initial inspiration for the story, the challenging shoot, and the record-breaking success, as well as the film’s endurance, examining the merchandising it inspired and the reasons E.T. holds a permanent place in the hearts of movie fans the world over.

But it: From the Academy Museum Store

'Fun City Cinema: New York City and the Movies that Made It' by Jason Bailey

The Big Apple has a history of filmmaking that is just as storied as Hollywood's own, which film critic and historian Jason Bailey explores here, reflecting on 100 years of movies made in New York City by way of one "iconic Gotham film" from each decade: The Jazz Singer (1927), King Kong (1933), The Naked City (1948), Sweet Smell of Success (1957), Midnight Cowboy (1969), Taxi Driver (1976), Wall Street (1987), Kids (1995), 25th Hour (2002), and Frances Ha (2012).

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'Gus Van Sant: The Art of Making Movies' by Katya Tylevich

Gus Van Sant earned his first Oscar nomination for directing the 1997 romantic drama Good Will Hunting, then earned a second nomination for directing the 2008 biopic Milk. The filmmaker had been steadily working for two decades prior to that first recognition, though, and continues making movies to this day. Writer Katya Tylevich spent years interviewing Van Sant to provide a candid look at his creative process.

Buy it: From Laurence King Publishing, Amazon, Barnes & Noble, IndieBound

'Howard Kazanjian: A Producer's Life' by J. W. Rinzler

Across his 50-year career, blockbuster film producer Howard G. Kazanjian has worked on such cinematic classics as The Empire Strikes Back and Raiders of the Lost Ark, in addition to collaborating with the likes of Alfred Hitchcock and Billy Wilder. This in-depth biography hails from writer and former LucasBooks editor J. W. Rinzler, with an introduction by Marcia Lucas, the Oscar-winning editor of Star Wars.

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'Leave the Gun, Take the Cannoli: The Epic Story of the Making of The Godfather' by Mark Seal

The Godfather is such a masterpiece that it's downright comical to think that, at one point in time, it seemed destined for disaster: Paramount Pictures had hired an unestablished filmmaker to direct a scandal-prone actor all while fending off the Italian Mafia at every turn. In spite of the obstacles that stood in its way, the film went on to become the highest grossing film ever made at the time, won three Oscars (including Best Picture), and remains – exactly 50 years later – one of the greatest films ever made, all of which is documented in Mark Seal's tome.

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'Masters of Make-Up Effects: A Century of Practical Magic' by Howard Berger and Marshall Julius

Oscar-winning makeup artist Howard Berger (The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and the Wardrobe) and film critic Marshall Julius wrote this definitive oral history, including untold stories from legends of the industry and never-before-seen photos of some of the most iconic makeup effects of all time. The tome includes a foreword from Guillermo del Toro and afterword by Seth MacFarlane.

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'The Method: How the Twentieth Century Learned to Act' by Isaac Butler

Tales of Method actors immersing themselves in their characters have been told for years. But what is Method acting? Critic and theater director Isaac Butler sets out to answer exactly that while providing a historical chronicle of the technique. Butler traces it back to Moscow in the late 1800s and documents the ways that Method acting has endured in Hollywood over the years.

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'Mike Nichols: A Life' by Mark Harris

Journalist Mark Harris explored the birth of a "New Hollywood" in his first book, Pictures at a Revolution, and the history of Hollywood during WWII in Five Came Back. For his third book, he focuses on a single director — the indelible Mike Nichols — to create this exhaustive account of the many successes and even the failures of his storied career, with interviews from the likes of Elaine May, Meryl Streep, Stephen Sondheim, Tom Hanks and Gloria Steinem.

Buy it: From Penguin Press, Amazon, Barnes & Noble, IndieBound

'Spike Lee: Director's Inspiration' by Spike Lee

The newest catalogue from The Academy Museum centers on the iconic and Oscar-winning Spike Lee — a Best Adapted Screenplay winner for BlacKkKlansman, a legend for joints like Do the Right Thing and She's Gotta Have It, Malcolm X and Da 5 Bloods. This volume presents the filmmaker's personal collection of original movie posters, photographs, artworks and more ― many of which are inscribed to Lee personally by directors, actors, athletes, activists, musicians and others who have inspired his work in specific ways.

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store

'These Fists Break Bricks: How Kung Fu Movies Swept America and Changed the World' by Chris Poggiali and Grady Hendrix

Having previously taken an encyclopedic approach to analyzing horror throughout the '70s and '80s, author Grady Hendrix now teams up with film historian Chris Poggiali to create the definitive history of Kung Fu movies in America. With a forward by RZA of the Wu-Tang Clan, These Fists Break Bricks begins with the 1973 release of Five Fingers of Death and tracks the genre's impact and influences far beyond cineplexes.

Buy it: From the Academy Museum Store
